fava.functionable
Class Range

java.lang.Object
  fava.functionable.Functionable<T>
      fava.functionable.Sequence<java.lang.Integer>
          fava.functionable.Range
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>
public class Range
extends Sequence<java.lang.Integer>

Represents a range of integer values including a step size. The representation of the range is inclusive of the upper bound value.

While convention is to make the upper bound exclusive, this does not work as well when step sizes are introduced. A range of 1..5 representing [1, 2, 3, 4] may work well, but a range of 3..9:3 representing only [3, 6] and not [3, 6, 9] makes the exclusive upper bound a less appealing notation in this case.

Author:
Nathaniel Sherry, 2009-2011

Constructor Detail

Range

public Range()
Creates an empty range representing no values. This is useful when attempting to create a a range which does not overlap with any other range.

Note: Because the upper bound is inclusive to prevent odd notation when dealing with step sizes other than 1, range(0,0) will represent 0<=x<=0 rather than the more conventional 0<=x<0, and so range(0,0) will contain 0 as its only value.

Range

public Range(int start,
             int stop)
Creates a new range from start to stop inclusive. While convention is to make the upper bound exclusive, this does not work as well when step sizes are introduced. A range of 1..5 representing [1, 2, 3, 4] may work well, but a range of 3..9:3 representing only [3, 6] and not [3, 6, 9] makes the exclusive upper bound a less appealing notation in this case.

Note: Because the upper bound is inclusive to prevent odd notation when dealing with step sizes other than 1, range(0,0) will represent 0<=x<=0 rather than the more conventional 0<=x<0, and so range(0,0) will contain 0 as its only value.

Parameters:
start - the starting value of this range
stop - the stopping value of this range (inclusive)

Range

public Range(int start,
             int stop,
             int step)
Creates a new range from start to stop inclusive. While convention is to make the upper bound exclusive, this does not work as well when step sizes are introduced. A range of 1..5 representing [1, 2, 3, 4] may work well, but a range of 3..9:3 representing only [3, 6] and not [3, 6, 9] makes the exclusive upper bound a less appealing notation in this case.

Note: Because the upper bound is inclusive to prevent odd notation when dealing with step sizes other than 1, range(0,0) will represent 0<=x<=0 rather than the more conventional 0<=x<0, and so range(0,0) will contain 0 as its only value.

Parameters:
start - the starting value of this range
stop - the stopping value of this range (inclusive)
step - the step size of this range
Method Detail

fromLength

public static Range fromLength(int start,
                               int length)
Creates a new range based on the length of the range rather than the upper bound value. fromLength(1, 3) will create a range representing the values [1, 2, 3]

Parameters:
start - the starting value of the range
length - the length of the range
Returns:
a new Range representing the parameters given

fromLength

public static Range fromLength(int start,
                               int length,
                               int stepsize)
Creates a new range based on the length of the range rather than the upper bound value. fromLength(1, 5, 2) will create a range representing the values [1, 3, 5]

Parameters:
start - the starting value of the range
length - the length of the range
stepsize - the stepsize of the range
Returns:
a new Range representing the parameters given

size

public int size()
The integer span of this Range. Note that for step sizes greater than 1, this is not the same as the number of elements in the range. To determine that value, call elementCount()

Returns:
the size of the span of the Range

elementCount

public int elementCount()
The number of elements contained in this Range. Note that for step sizes greater than 1, this is not the same as the size (span) of the Range.

Returns:
the number of integer values included in this Range

isOverlapping

public boolean isOverlapping(Range other)
Determines if this Range is overlapping with another Range. Ranges which overlap by start and end position, but which have different step sizes, or have the same step size, but out of phase, are considered to be not truly overlapping. This allows for the creation of more complex patterns using RangeSet, such as joining two ranges: eg (1, 4, 7, 10) and (2, 5, 8, 11) to produce (1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 10, 11)

Parameters:
other - the other Range to compare against
Returns:
true if the two Ranges contain common elements with a common step size, false otherwise

isAdjacent

public boolean isAdjacent(Range other)
Determines if two Ranges are adjacent. Ranges are considered adjacent if
  • Their step sizes match
  • They are in phase
  • The starting value of one is one step after the stopping value of the other

Parameters:
other - the other Range to examine
Returns:
true if the two Ranges are one step apart from each other, with the same step and phase, false otherwise

isTouching

public boolean isTouching(Range other)
Equivalent to isOverlapping(Range) OR isAdjacent(Range)

Parameters:
other - the Range to check this Range against
Returns:
true if the two ranges are overlapping or touching, false otherwise

merge

public Range merge(Range other)
Merges two Ranges for which isTouching(Range) returns true. Returns null if the Ranges do not satisfy this requirement.

Parameters:
other - the other Range to merge this Range with
Returns:
a new Range representing the union of the elements of both

difference

public RangeSet difference(Range other)
Returns a RangeSet representing this Range with the elements in the other Range removed. The Ranges must satisfy isOverlapping(Range). If the Ranges are not overlapping, then the returned RangeSet will simply represent this Range

Parameters:
other - the Range to remove from this Range
Returns:
a RangeSet representing elements in this Range which are not in the other Range

Get the start value of this Range

the lower bound and first element in this Range

Returns:
the upper bound of this Range

getStep

public int getStep()
Get the step size of this Range

Returns:
the interval between consecutive elements in this Range
